entry.title: Etchmiadzin Cathedral reopens after years-long renovation

media:group.media:title: Etchmiadzin Cathedral reopens after years-long renovation
media:group.media:description:
üìç The Etchmiadzin Cathedral was reopened yesterday after 12 years of renovation during a ceremony attended by Armenia‚Äôs prime minister, Nikol Pashinyan, President Vahagn Khachaturyan, and other high-ranking officials. üìç Armenia‚Äôs Foreign Minister Ararat Mirzoyan met with Palestinian Prime Minister Mohammad Mustafa, establishing diplomatic relations between the countries. üìç THIS WEEK IN BUSINESS: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fxNzC0dQOkw üìç Armenian civil society missed responsibilities: civilnet.am/en/news/798803/the-cost-of-compliance-armenian-civil-societys-missed-responsibilities/ üìç Women‚Äôs representation in Armenia‚Äôs politics: civilnet.am/en/news/798707/womens-representation-in-armenian-government-growing-but-still-limited-experts-say/

entry.title: What can Armenia expect from hosting the world's largest tech conference?

media:group.media:title: What can Armenia expect from hosting the world's largest tech conference?
media:group.media:description:
Hayk Karapetyan, executive director of the organizing committee for this year‚Äôs World Conference on Innovation and Technology, joins CivilNet‚Äôs Mark Dovich to talk about what Armenia can get from hosting the summit, one of the world‚Äôs largest and most prestigious events of its kind. They also review the state of Armenia‚Äôs burgeoning technology sector, including what role the country can play in the artificial intelligence revolution, and where the industry can go from here.
Yerevan will host the World Conference on Innovation and Technology on October 4-7. It marks the second time Armenia is hosting the event.
0:00 What will happen at this year‚Äôs WCIT? 1:30 What role can Armenia play in the AI revolution? 3:00 What can Armenia get from hosting WCIT? 4:30 How has Armenia‚Äôs tech sector changed in recent years? 5:32 How to turn Armenia into a regional tech hub? 7:05 What role can the government play in the IT sector? 8:11 Where will the tech industry go in the next 10 years?

entry.title: Gazprom to sell Armenian hotel, CivilNet investigation finds: THIS WEEK IN BUSINESS

media:group.media:title: Gazprom to sell Armenian hotel, CivilNet investigation finds: THIS WEEK IN BUSINESS
media:group.media:description:
üìç Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan‚Äôs cabinet put forward a budget proposal for next year that envisages Armenia‚Äôs economy to expand by 5.6%. The government plans total revenues to approach $7.5 billion, while expenditures are expected to top $9 billion. üìç Babken Tunyan, a leading pro-government lawmaker, dismissed speculation that the government is, apparently, considering nationalizing the country‚Äôs main electric utility. üìç The United Kingdom-based company that owns Vorotan, Armenia‚Äôs largest hydroelectric power plant, plans to invest an additional $14.4 million in the facility through 2026. üìç The Armenian subsidiary of Gazprom, the Russian state-owned energy giant, is trying to sell off a hotel it owns in the resort town of Tsaghkadzor, a CivilNet investigation found.

media:group.media:title: Pashinyan‚Äôs cabinet proposes to boost military budget
media:group.media:description:
üìç New York City Mayor Eric Adams allegedly took bribes from the Turkish government in exchange for not making a statement on the Armenian Genocide and for using his power to fast-track the construction of a Turkish consulate in the city. üìç Nikol Pashinyan, spoke yesterday at this year‚Äôs United Nations General Assembly, reiterating that the Armenian Constitution has no territorial claims toward Azerbaijan and stressing that the two countries are close to signing a normalization deal. üìç Armenia plans on increasing its military budget by 20% next year, up to roughly $1.73 billion, according to the budget proposal approved by the country‚Äôs cabinet yesterday. üìç Insights with Eric Hacopian: https://youtu.be/prIEcFg7G9Q?si=R_IW7E9cVJPafUXR
